# JOINT AFFIDAVIT.
## ARMY PENSION—WIDOW CLAIMANT.

We, John Dixon, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, at James Sutton, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, upon our claim, jointly declare that he was personally well acquainted with Mrs. Kean Chambers, widow of (1) Aaron Chambers, now deceased, and was not sent to Private in Company E, commanded by Captain Moore, in the 1818 Regiment of (2) United States Colored Volunteers, commanded by Colonel Moore, in the war of 1776-1778.

We further declare that we were likewise personally well acquainted with the said (1) Aaron Chambers, deceased, and his said wife, the said Mrs. Kean Chambers, during the lifetime of the former, and know that they lived and exhibited together as husband and wife for the period at least of (2) Twenty years prior to his death, which length of time in the longest period of cohabitation, known to us. That said parties were reported as husband and wife, and that we never heard a question raised or a doubt concerned to the contrary as to their being such. Furthermore, we have often heard the said (1) Aaron Chambers call the said Mrs. Kean Chambers "wife," and always heard him speak of, and know that he ever treated and suspected her as such relation. We also state that she is esteemed and known as a respectable woman in the community of her residence.

We further declare that at the time of service, we resided in the army, established, County and State with the deceased soldier, and know that he, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, previous to his entering the said service of the United States, was a man of good sound physical health. Our knowledge of said soldier's physical condition prior to enlistment, as above stated, is finished upon several observations and intimate acquaintance with him and not heard upon information derived from others, nor upon general reason. That he died (1) While in the service aforesaid in the (1) United States, in the State of Virginia on or about the Sixth day of November A.D. 1864, from the effects of (2) Wounds, described in the service of the United States, and as we verily believe from general reports, and without the slightest doubt to the contrary, while in the line of his duty therein. That Mrs. Kean Chambers, his widow aforesaid, applying for Army Pension by reason of the above named military service, is now a widow, and has remained such ever since the death of her said husband, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, above mentioned. That we make this affidavit as a simple act of justice to the applicant, and for an other purpose, having an interest in so doing whatsoever. That we fully understand the import and meaning of all the facts embodied in this affidavit, and to which we freely testify.

B. E. Thornton
J. T. Weller
John Dixon

We, H. C. Hinkle, Jr. and W. D. Chambers, Clerk of the County of Henderson, do the same to certify, and will acquainted with Aaron Chambers, dec'd, late a private in Co. "I" 186th Regt. U.S.C.T. Infty., who died, as we verily believe, while in the U.S. service on or about the 6th day of November 1864.

He also states that we are well acquainted with Rea Chambers, who is making application for a pension, or widow of Abneris (a) Aaron Chambers, and knew that she is the true and lawful widow of said infirm dec'd.

That they were more generally married for the reason that the laws of Kentucky did not require a Consul and record or Lawful marriage for pensions of color, but recognized them as man and wife from the act of constitution. That the aforesaid Rea and Aaron Chambers communicate living together as man and wife on or about 18th day of April AD 1857, and continued to live together as such until the decease of aforesaid Aaron, according to custom of persons of color in the state of Kentucky.

That we have often heard said Aaron Chambers call his (Rea) Chambers, wife, and always treated and respected her in such relation. That they were considered as man and wife by all their neighbors and acquaintances, and considered respectable in the community in which they lived.

That there are now living men of their said Aaron and Rea Chambers under the age of sixteen years. And that she has been a widow since the death of above named soldier (Aaron Chambers) dec'd.

That we have 30 acres in the Valley

H. C. Hinkle, Jr.

Park, a Notary Public, I certify that the law of the State of Kentucky, is entitled to credit for the services rendered and paid by him, and that the pensioner is entitled to receive a pension of the 7th of July, 1866, being by me duly sworn according to law, on oath, that he is the true and lawful widow of Solomon Charles, decd. late a Private Company, Co. 111th U.S. Inf. Infantry, who died in field Hospital, State of Virginia, on the 21st day of November, 1866, from the affiant of Christian Anderson, for the time of duty.

She further declares she is unable to obtain a certificate from the Surgeon of this Regiment or Company, Virginia, for the reason that they were all withheld and do not reside in the Community of the residence and in lieu of the above named certificate. She lives with said, the affidavit of two of his fellow soldiers, as to the cause and place of the claim, it being the best evidence she is able to obtain.

She further swears, she cannot send record proof of her marriage with the above mentioned soldier, and for the reason that the law of the State, did not require a license & a record for the marriage of Charles of Color, but requires them as man and wife from the act of Collection and he (Harm) & her lived together as man and wife according to the cause in Kentucky for persons of color, in proof of which she live with and the affidavit of two or another witnesses.

Denn H. Chambers
